bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Alberto Recio, May 1, 1941

div1.p: Hench hopes that the sites affiliated with the conquest of yellow fever will be memorialized. Hench solicits Recio' help in obtaining a statement from the Cuban government as evidence that it accepted Hench's report on the actual site of Camp Lazear. He offers to write an abstract of the report for a Cuban medical journal, and hopes that the Cuban media will also be informed of the discovery.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Alberto Recio, May 1, 1941
div1.opener:
Copy to Mr. Moran
May 1, 1941
Dr. Alberto Recio
Ave. de la Independencia y Montero
Habana, Cuba
My dear Doctor Recio:
div1.p:
I appreciate very much indeed your kind letter of April 22 in which
you said that you had read my report to Dr. Ramos and find it to be true to the best
of your knowledge. It has been a most interesting experience for me to be permitted
to “rediscover Camp Lazear” and to help locate the sites where such wonderful work
was done, on behalf of the conquest of yellow fever. I feel greatly encouraged to
have the great interest of yourself and Dr. Ramos, and I sincerely hope that I can
interest enough American friends so that we can memorialize these sites properly.
It may be necessary to call on your government for their formal approval and perhaps
even their help, but I am hoping that the group of American physicians can make
this gesture to the Cuban government and the medical profession, without outside help.

Do you remember the morning you, Dr. Ramos and I happened to meet in
the library of the Finlay Institute, when Dr. Ramos dictated to Miss Malaret, formally
accepting my report? It was to be translated into English, and an English and Spanish
copy were to be sent to me within the next three or four days. I have not yet re-
ceived this. My local ambassador, Mr. Moran, has done his best to get it for me,
but I gather that Dr. Ramos has been very busy and has been out of town also. Would
it be asking too much for you to discreetly inquire from Miss Malaret as to whether
I can expect to receive this shortly? You will understand that it is so much easier
for me to approach my American friends for financial support when I have definite
evidence that the Cuban government has accepted my report and believes that we have
truly discovered the site of Camp Lazear and the remains of Building No. 1.

It was a great pleasure for me to meet you and I shall take the
liberty, as Dr. Ramos suggested, of keeping you informed of my further activities
in behalf of our project. Anything that you can do to help me by interesting other
members of your government, I will appreciate most sincerely. Now that Dr. Ramos and
you have read and accepted my report, do you think it would be feasible to publicize
it somewhat? Would it be best to have a report come from Dr. Ramos' office to the
newspapers? Would it be acceptable to have me write an abstract of the report for
a Cuban medical journal? I shall do nothing without the full approval of yourself
and Dr. Ramos.

I am having sent to you with our compliments the Proceedings of the
Mayo Clinic Staff Meetings, which should reach you regularly and which I hope you
will find of interest.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
